config_data.description: Mobile-first dashboard for the football GM simulation game. Main hub after career creation where users manage their team. Features a bottom tab bar navigation with 5 tabs (Home, Roster, Schedule, Draft, Settings) and displays key information about the user's team and career progress.
config_data.goal: Create an engaging, information-rich dashboard that serves as the central hub for all GM activities, providing quick access to team status, upcoming games, and core management features while maintaining the mobile-first design language.
requirements: Bottom tab bar with 5 functional tabs: Home, Roster, Schedule, Draft, Settings
Home tab displays team card, upcoming game preview, and quick stats
Tab navigation updates URL and renders correct content
Maintain selected team and persona data from career store
Mobile-first responsive design matching existing app aesthetic
Each tab has its own dedicated content area
constraints: Must work with existing Zustand career store
No external API calls - all data is local/generated
Mobile-first design (max-width 500px centered)
Use existing shadcn/ui components and Tailwind styles
Tabs other than Home can be placeholder/mock for now

1_executive_summary.description: Mobile-first dashboard for the football GM simulation game. Main hub after career creation where users manage their team. 1_executive_summary.goal: Create an engaging, information-rich dashboard that serves as the central hub for all GM activities, providing quick access to team status, upcoming games, and core management features while maintaining the mobile-first design language.

1_executive_summary.description: Refactor the codebase to use a modular component architecture where each dev tools card (Generator, View, Gameplay Loop) corresponds to a reusable module. The Full Game page imports and composes these same modules, ensuring consistency across the application.
1_executive_summary.goal: Single source of truth for each module - update once, updates everywhere. Dev tools becomes testing ground, Full Game becomes composition layer.
1_executive_summary.problem_statement: Currently there is duplication between dev tools pages and full game sections. roster-view/page.tsx (500 LOC) and roster-section.tsx (200 LOC) do similar things with different UIs. This causes maintenance burden and UI inconsistency.
1_executive_summary.solution: Extract core logic into module components with a 'mode' prop that controls standalone vs embedded behavior. Both dev tools and full game import the same module.

in_scope: Create src/components/modules/ directory structure
Extract RosterView module (merge roster-view page + roster-section)
Extract ScheduleView module from schedule-section
Move StandingsView and StatsView to modules
Extract ScoutingLoop module from scouting-section
Create TrainingLoop wrapper module
Update GameplayLoop to import modules
Update dev tools pages to use modules with page wrappers
Delete deprecated section components
out_of_scope: Adding new features or gameplay mechanics
Changing API endpoints or data structures
Generator modules (GameSetupDashboard pattern is already good)

risks.mitigation: Refactor one module at a time, test after each extraction, keep old files until new ones verified

risks.description: Props interface mismatches between standalone and embedded usage
risks.mitigation: Design flexible interfaces with sensible defaults, use TypeScript for compile-time checking
Use mode prop to control height/padding, avoid hardcoded dimensions
Pass onPlayerClick callback instead of hardcoding router.push

vulnerabilities.summary: Next.js is vulnerable to RCE in React flight protocol
vulnerabilities.details:
A vulnerability affects certain React packages<sup>1</sup> for versions 19.0.0, 19.1.0, 19.1.1, and 19.2.0 and frameworks that use the affected packages, including Next.js 15.x and 16.x using the App Router. The issue is tracked upstream as [CVE-2025-55182](https://www.cve.org/CVERecord?id=CVE-2025-55182). 

Fixed in:
React: 19.0.1, 19.1.2, 19.2.1
Next.js: 15.0.5, 15.1.9, 15.2.6, 15.3.6, 15.4.8, 15.5.7, 16.0.7

The vulnerability also affects experimental canary releases starting with 14.3.0-canary.77. Users on any of the 14.3 canary builds should either downgrade to a 14.x stable release or 14.3.0-canary.76.

All users of stable 15.x or 16.x Next.js versions should upgrade to a patched, stable version immediately.

<sup>1</sup> The affected React packages are:
- react-server-dom-parcel
- react-server-dom-turbopack
- react-server-dom-webpack
